item.title: 'Pepper' pool.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4266" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Pepper"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4267" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Ozzie- frontside air"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4268" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Kale Sandridge-FS 50-50/deathbox w Reuler & Salba watching."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4269" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Andy Macdonald- frontside nosebone."][/caption] I was visiting California from Pennsylvania's 'Woodward' skate camp in 1994. It was cold at the airport in Philadelphia. Snow was falling & they kept 'de-icing' the huge jet wings, while I sat there & watched. I --idly--wondered in my own macabre way, if I was going to crash on the way up or once aloft. Somehow, the thought of hurtling at 300+ MPH into the earth....kinda felt nice. Anyway, we finally arrived & Andy Macdonald picked me up in San Diego. The next morning, Andy, Jon 'Bacon' Hobbs, Rhino, Preston & I, drove up to Salbaland to ride backyard pools. Salba met us outside his garage. We loaded up, buckets, pumps, brooms & a 'turkey baster'. I looked sideways at Rhino and he quickly informed me that,"...the 'turkey baster' gets the water out of the drain hole, when you cannot remove the drain cover".  "Oh....." I mumbled. It was the start of a 'brave new world' for me. We went to numerous pools that day. It was a blur of dirt, graffiti, broken beer bottles, refuse, human decadence, poverty & filth. It was also one of the most wonderful experiences of my life. I had found exactly what I had been looking for all my life. It may sound odd, but I love pool skating. When I rode with these guys & carved over the light-- grinding-- it was epic. I felt the speed & knew I needed more. I remember that I didn't do well that day. I rode vert often, my trucks were too tight & I kept kickturning...a 'no-no' in pool riding, because you lose ALL of your speed. They were patient, probably because of my enthusiasm. The final pool of the day was one that Salba found. He called it 'Pepper'.  It was a 'Master' pool by Jim Hendricks. 'Pepper' was a right-hand kidney with smooth, shiny bullnose coping, a deathbox left of the light & steep side hip stairs. The surface was fast & smooth. Palm trees hung in the sky overhead. It was an image straight out of 'Skateboarder' magazine. Salba told us the crazy story of finding & draining it the first time. "When we found out and bailed it for the first time, I was scared shitless because wasps were using the water for their wasp nests. There were hundreds --if not thousands-- of wasps. I  am allergic to bee stings...'epi-pen' bad! Anyhow,  Slide 540 was just laughing at me & swatting those wasps away with his hands. It got so bad that I jumped back over the brick wall, until Slide got the rest of the water out. 'Pepper' lasted for about a year and a half, just sitting there 'H.U.D. house' style....then this Mexican family moved in and we thought it was finished. But much to our amazement, they let us ride,  for a case of beer. After that, I got to know them real good...in fact I took my boys there often and they played with the kids there.........mind you-- my kid Jesse was like two to three years old at the time. He would sit there, playing in the dirt with his cars and motorcycles when we rode the pool.........epic!" Salba had us laughing with his memories of the pool. On my visit, we rode there until dark that night. I saw things that defied logic. I saw Andy Mac pull waist high FS nosebones. I saw Salba roll-in, then fly through the pool, going over every obstacle. I saw standup 5-0 grinds on the shallow end coping. I saw 'Bacon' pull FS boneless & FS airs. I was drop-jawed in amazement! These guys destroyed that pool. On the long ride home, in the dark stuffy confines of Andy's Honda Civic, I made up my mind to move to California. I knew I would live here & ride pools.  Visiting 'Pepper' pool was a turning point for me. I will never forget it. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Buster Halterman.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4283" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Buster- going huge!"]
[/caption] [caption id="attachment_4297" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Buster- kickflip varial"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4298" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Buster-lipslide up & over"][/caption]
Buster-frontside corner air @ Bellmars
[caption id="attachment_4284" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Buster-'Madonna' @ Bellmars"][/caption] Buster Halterman is probably one of the greatest vert skateboarders ever to ride. He is my all-time favorite. Buster & Chris Miller are quite similar in style. Both flow effortlessly & go super huge! It shouldn't strike anyone as 'odd' that Chris Miller chose Buster to be a pro rider on his fledgling company, 'Planet Earth' back in 1990. I met Buster back behind the 'flannel curtain' in Pennsylvania. Buster had a huge vert ramp in his barn about an hour from my house. I would drive up there & we would all ride. When I say "we", I mean, Buster, Kook Rinker, Zahn, Dave & Chris Cohara, Mike Breen (R.I.P.), Scott Ward, Squim, Carlos, Pete Sandman, Choppy, Jim Howell, Jason Wagner,Thor,  and a few others that came often. The decks were full of vert riders 'hooting & hollaring' at each other. Buster was ramp lord & master. No joke! He tore like no other. At 16 years old, he was better & more stylish than anyone out there...except maybe his 'influence', Chris Miller. Buster & his family took me in, when my life unraveled in 1992. I went to school to become an RN & lived there with them. We rode vert regularly & they are some of the best memories of my life. Buster was instrumental in getting me into Woodward, where I became 'Director' of the Skate program. Once I moved to California, Buster would sometimes ride pools or Vans with us. I took him to Kelly Bellmars pool, & he tore it apart. He was a huge influence on my life & I owe him & his family a debt of gratitude I can -hopefully- one day  repay.Thanks to Dan Bourqui for the vert images.  Skate & be good to your friends- Ozzie

item.title: 'Combi pool' flashback.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4308" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Christian Hosoi- O.G. Combi. Variflex pro/am 1985."][/caption] The Vans Combi II,  is fairly far along with its major 'rejuvenation'. Its going to be insanely awesome and-- make no mistake about it-- this years Vans/ ProTec Combi contest will be one for all-time! I was told that the pool is pretty close to being completed. The hips into the shallow need a bit of work but the flat, corners, walls in the square & the round pool are --virtually--done. I was also told that the new coping is super rad! "It's nicely done & rock hard for grinding."  I heard that the new coping has those really great pebble pits & holes that give good pool coping some 'bite'. I am anxious. On 'Combi-II' opening night in November of 1998, I was fortunate enough to have had my pal, Andy Macdonald, acquire me an invitation for the first session. I still have the 'pass & wheel' that was given to riders. I recently rode in the 'last session' before they started work on it. I am anticipating the grand re-opening soon.  No more bumps, imperfections or slippery surfaces. Get ready, because it's going to be amazing. Steve Van Doren & the crew rule it. Here is a great image of Christian Hosoi at the Variflex Pro/Am in 1985,  at the O.G. Pipeline Combi. Thank you to J.Grant Brittain for the perfect image. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Buddy Nichols & Rick Charnoski.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4325" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Rick Charnoski- 'kink sink' @ 'Spinning Wheels' Reading PA."]
[/caption]
Buddy Nichols- Hollywood.
http://www.sixstair.com/ I met Buddy Nichols back in the mid-late 1990s. I met him through an old Pennsylvania vert pal--Rick Charnoski. In 1999, they were both in California to film their 'breakthrough' video, 'Fruit of the Vine'. This video has become the measuring stick for every other pool documentary or video since. These guys set the bar quite high! During filming, TA & I had been riding the 'Gonzales pool'. I asked TA if we could bring the crew over & he--of course--readily agreed. The footage & session from that day was super rad. Buddy & Rick have gone on to write, direct & produce a wide array of projects & DVDs. Recently, I have seen them at Lance Mountains pool & in the 'Badlands.' We have ridden numerous pools together & these guys are ripping & documenting our-- collective-- history. Check out the 'Six stair' link above & see for yourself, the high level of insane ripping & artistic expression that these two are involved in. Thank you to Geoff Graham for the images. Skate & support your pool pals- Ozzie

item.title: idiot convention.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_3736" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Josh- FS disaster@ Jungle bowl."][/caption] "I told my psychiatrist that everyone hates me. He said I was being ridiculous - everyone hasn't met me yet." -Rodney Dangerfield. Sometimes, the world of skateboarding is an 'idiot convention'. I go to events & see guys strutting about, puffed with pride & self-importance...it kinda makes me laugh. They walk around, looking left & right to see who's watching them. I saw a guy like this last weekend. He moved through the crowd like he was being photographed. Most of them look like they skate, but cannot. They would be useless in a pool. That guy I saw, probably wouldn't be useful as toilet paper for my ass. Many live on lies & excuses. Some guys, live in a bubble. If we popped  it, they would fart & fall from their-- self-imposed-- lofty perch. Its a tragedy. If they got off the couch long enough, they would see the dust & cobwebs gathering on their skateboard. Hopefully, they -then-could put the beer away & go re-kindle the damned flame. But, enough of my indignation. I know that you all get tired of me, ranting. Hell! I get tired of me! Here's one that knows how to stay hungry & keep it real. Josh Borden. FS disaster. First try. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: 'Mi numi'
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4338" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Dave Hackett. Valley Center 1977"][/caption] This weekend was the 'Clash at Clairmont' in San Diego. Its an event that raises money for cancer victims. 'Grind for Life' has these events & they are really important. I have worked with cancer & AIDS patients as an RN and can tell you that these people need the help & support. The event was amazing & an incredible level of skateboarding was witnessed by the crowd attending. Today, I awoke & had the opportunity to ride a backyard pool with Dave Hackett & Aaron Astorga. Ray, Christian & I met with them & we drove over to the pool. It was stellar. I looked around as I cleaned & swept the deep end. Colorful purple-flowering vines covered the fences, a blue sky hung over everything & the hot sun felt great on our backs. Cleaning & toweling, I looked over & saw Dave Hackett sweeping the plaster alongside me. I smiled and--in that moment--knew that everything was perfect. Here we were. Ray, Christian, Aaron, Dave & I; a few old pool pals still out there doing this thing we do. 'Mi numi'. Literally, it means, 'my gods'.  More deeply, it invokes a pre-Christian pagan world ruled by the religion of the Numa; a time when the gods determined every mans  fate or destiny. 'Mi numi'. This is my fate & destiny...this thing we do. We all rode into the early afternoon. Lines were flowing, tricks were pulled & smiles were everywhere. What occurred today, is the reason I now cherish my existence. I try to remember what is important in my life & throwing down some carve lines with a few pool pals... has to fit in somewhere  'high' on the list. Thanks to Jim Goodrich for the image-Skate-Ozzie

item.title: The company you keep.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4395" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Cab & Christian @ Venice contemplating the plight of humanity."][/caption] 'Experience is cheap, if that's the company you keep." [caption id="attachment_4389" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="'Lawyers'"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4390" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Aaron Astorga, Dave Hackett, Bluetile Ozzie, Christian BlkPrjkt."][/caption] We should all know how great it feels, to be in a flowing session with some great friends on a Sunday morning. There's not much that compares. "Like most amazing things, it's easy to miss, and easy to mistake." Call some skate friends this week & prepare a session. Next Saturday night, limit the brews & buds, get sleep, get up, get out & get busy. Its amazing how great you'll feel Sunday evening & how stoked you'll feel, knowing you were crushing coping instead of beer cans. Thanks to 'M', Ken Samuels and MRZ for the images & Aimee Mann for the inspiration. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Oasis.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Plans for this weekend were 'up in the air' until last night. I received a text from Lance Mountain saying that he was available to go ride backyards with me out in Indio. I have a great pool pal out there in the desert: Doug Kinkade. Doug always has a deep bag of pools & loves to have outside company. I had planned to get out to the desert & skate with Doug before the season grows too hot. In the summer months, it can regularly top 120 degrees. You're not going to believe me, but out there, even I think people should have pools with water in them...at least until October or so.
The injured Samwise came out to 'Ridiculous' last night & I found him curled up on my couch this morning when I awoke. Lance met up with us & Deville from Powell came along. We drove the windy roads to Palm Springs & met with Doug by 11 am. The largest city in the Coachella Valley, Indio was originally known as Indian Wells, but the name was changed in 1879. Indio was a construction camp during the building of the Southern Pacific Railroad, and afterward it was the site of sprawling railway yards. In 1894, a local businessman laid out a township and began selling lots. The pools went in during the post- war boom of 1946. During World War II, General Patton was a regular out there & many servicemen ended up in Indio, starting families in the inexpensive neighborhoods that stretched out under the hot desert sun.
Anyway, we linked up with Doug, went over the plans & purchased drinks at 7-11. It was hot & the sun baked the sand & cactus. We stopped & checked out a few backyards. We were looking for something specific. Something odd & different. We found a new one. Huge palm trees scraped the sky & the dried grass crunched underfoot. The pool was a massive amoeba pool. Palm fronds were littering the bowl of the deep end. Plywood covered the yawning holes where shattered windows once were in the adjacent rundown house.
I saw a large mottled lizard peer up at me from a rock & quickly disappear under the scrub brush. We swept & prepared the pool. Lance worked into things slowly, trying to figure out the lines. Doug started carving deep to shallow, with ultimate board control & finesse. We pushed into the hot afternoon, with each of us trying to master the impossibly difficult, buckled & uneven plaster walls. Deville took some shots & all ended happily. We left, stopped for drinks & continued into our journey.
We had one more to discover. Doug has a few permission pools that are regular staples for him & his pals. This one Rossmore kidney he has...is stellar. We arrived, greeted 'Ricky' the owners son, unbolted the diving board & hit it hard. Lance pulled FS and BS airs, flying around the pool with ease. Doug ran rock-n-roll boardslides over the shallow end deathbox & BS ollies with Teflon style. I and the others all got ours as well. Samwise is still injured & took photographs, cheering us on. It was an epic 'Big Day Out' with Doug Kinkade. Afterwards, we all ate dinner together & were super-stoked with our adventures that day. Good friends, sunny weather & fantastic pools. It couldn't have been better. Thank you to Doug Kinkade for the pools, Deville for the images, Samwise for being...wise, and Lance for being....Lance. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Easter
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4429" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="David Hackett. pipe-to-pipe ollie 1978"][/caption] I'm not sure just how religious you are, but I am hoping that many of you are 'spiritual' in nature. It would be a start in the right direction. This is the road I am on. I write about it often; my inner conflicts & the nature of good and evil. Today is Easter Sunday. I am going to Easter services for the first time in....well, a long while. I see the teachings of the bible as a road map for 'right living'. If you treat people with respect, help others, be humble & selfless, you end up in a good place & find peace. That makes great sense to me. Have a good holiday today & please think on these things. Thanks to Dave Hackett for the image. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Palm Desert Oasis.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: One day last fall, Lance Mountain had told me that he wished he could find a backyard pool which had a set of side stairs rideable for an 'invert'. I -of course- started looking through my vast collection of pool images for just the pool. I had left & right kidneys, amoebas, capsules, squares, romans & rossmore kidneys.I finally found what I was looking for, deep into the archive. It was a pool with quite a colorful & interesting history. Joe's pool. Deep into the Coachella valley, neighborhoods spread out into the hot, flat distance. The sun scorches & bakes during the summer months, climbing upwards of 120 f. People need pools to escape the heat just as much as I need pools to live. Its difficult to tell when a home is in 'foreclosure' out here, because there are rarely any lawns & everything is screened up & shaded from the sun. Blinds & windows are closed, red lava rocks & thorny cactus crowd the remaining spaces around the homes, and they have a strange 'un-lived' in look, peculiar to the area. Its like being on Mars. In the fall of 2000, when I lived with Andy Macdonald in San Diego, I drove over & picked up Texas Dan. We were going on a 'grid mission' out into the desert. We drove out past Joshua Tree & started a patterned grid search of the neighborhoods. We systematically checked only older areas built in the 1950s & 1960s. After finding & grinding a few holes, we came upon a tiny hidden street in a back bend of a neighborhood. It was easy to miss & we were lucky that day. We saw a 'For Sale' sign & quickly pulled in. The house had a swimmer but looking over the opposing fence, we became really stoked. A perfect bone-dry 'Blue Haven' right hand kidney, was sitting there glittering in the mid day sun. The trannies at the hip were mellow & it appeared pristine to our starving eyes. An older lady lived there & we asked if we could take a few turns. She let us ride for 15 minutes. It was epic. The next year, Salba & I drove out & rode it again with her permission. This time a younger man came out. He said his name was 'Joe'. This was his moms house where he grew up. He said they would swim in the pool until 1988, then the pumps & filter broke so it sat empty. He let us ride it, then it was lost to us again. After Lance told me about wanting a pool for a side stairs 'invert', I thought of 'Joe's'. I phoned my pal in the desert, Doug Kinkade & he told me that he had that pool on 'lockdown' forever. He was bros with Joe. He set up a session. I left 'Ridiculous' with Ray Zimmerman of 'Concrete Disciples', Michael Serna Jr., Salba, Billy, Adam 12, Lance Mountain, Josh Borden & Peter King. It was a caravan. Supposedly, Joe stated that it was the last session. The house was going on the market or something. We were ready. We mopped the pool with CLR and dried it out. Doug Kinkade had drained a bit of water out with his son that morning, so it was all good. Salba & Billy started 'heckling' all of us. "Do the box pusscake." and on-and-on, ad nauseum. I did the box FS just to hush them up...and it worked. At least for a few peaceful minutes. Salba really knows how to push the crew & make us charge. Its good. Lance tore into the pool. It seemed like he hadn't skated in awhile, because he rode 'wide-open' on the gas pedal! FS airs over the box, FS grinds over the box, 'eggplants' and rock-n-rolls' were served up double quick. Sean Mazza & Aaron showed up & rolled in. Both pulled light box & destroyed. Sean was served up a plaster blast after trying a footplant. He sat out for awhile. Salba pulled Salba lines & lived up to his old namesake-'La Machine'. He did light box/ box light, and completely ruled it. Serna & Adam 12 along with Billy, hit the switch & mixed it up with long 5-0s & side stair ladder 'thread the needle' grinds.Doug Kinkade has been to Joes pool before---it shows. Doug smoothly floated BS ollies over the hip into the shallow cup. It was perfection. Peter King told us an interesting story. In 1988, he was flying in a Cessna out of Palm Springs & spotted this very pool from the air. Later, he went back & found it. He put the first grind marks on the coping along with '540 slide'. Pk & '540' were chased out of the yard by a younger guy. It turned out to be Joe. Funny. Today though, PK crushed the box FS, then on his second pass, hit the side stair but the side stair hit back. PK quickly found his 200+ pounds, pounded into the drain. He came up slowly & has been on the DL ever since. Get better bro. Josh Borden is no slouch. The guy rips! He is becoming one of my favorite guys to ride with. Crail slides over the box, indy pointer nose picks, disasters and anything else he wanted, was served up fast & stylish. MRZ shot a ton of pics & the family at the house took a few as well. It was awesome to be in the desert, under a sunny sky, riding such an epic pool with great skate friends. Thank you Joe. You rule it. Ozzie

item.title: relationshits
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4259" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Me- thrusting against the only 'lip' I can handle."][/caption] Q: Why do men die before their wives? A: They want to. Celibacy is the  rule. Until I find out whats wrong with my head, my hand remains the only one holding mine. I can't hang any longer. When they were handing out the 'winning hand' at the card table of love, I must have been taking a crap in the bathroom. I returned & found myself 'shit outta luck'. Why is it that women have a set of rules for men, then a whole other set for themselves? I saw a bumper sticker the other day. "If it has tits or tires, there's gonna be problems.' Why is it that a woman can gripe & complain-ad nauseum- about skating & yet she doesn't want to hear it when we find her things unimportant? Why are relationships so difficult?  Why do we surrender our will & pretend to like walking stupid dogs that wear sweaters? Why do we shuffle through town--bored & disinterested-- looking in shop windows that sell the same dumb stuff we will never need? Why do they need continual reassurances of their desirability yet we receive nothing in return except more grief & financial hardship? Why is it that she gets the Audi A4 & we get the Honda Civic? Tell me! Why have we let it get to this point? Some women have a sense of 'entitlement' that is only matched by their absolute knowledge that most men will do anything, to continue worshiping at that silky skin altar,  for just one more night. I see it everyday....its a tragedy. We sold ourselves gentlemen. Relationships are the shits. If you find this 'harsh' or unpalatable, you have my apologies.  I find that its actually quite funny. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Katrina Crew
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4443" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="digital disaster"] [/caption] [caption id="attachment_4444" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="peanut after"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4445" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="peanut in its useful state..."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4446" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption=""when the levee breaks...""][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4447" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="mudbuddy"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4436" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="dirty holes"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4437" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="flat"]
[/caption] [caption id="attachment_4440" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="the hopper"][/caption]
[caption id="attachment_4438" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="dirt"][/caption] Some pool pals that choose anonymity, made contact with me through the 'Blue Tile Obsession' a few months back. It seems we share the same interest & I found that they had a story to tell. Here is one of the 'Katrina Crews' version of the 'Katrina' debacle."Before August 29, 2005 there was no 'pool scene' in New Orleans, Louisiana. There were about three of us,  that searched for pools but mostly came up empty handed. If you wanted to skate a pool, you had to drive to Texas, which we did on more than one occasion. In 2004, we purchased a three inch, 5.5 horsepower trash pump.  It really didn't go to work until after 'Katrina'. Today, our pump--the 'MUTHA SUCKA'--has drained over 50 pools in New Orleans and the surrounding area. Our group of pool riding friends has grown a little but the goal remains the same. Find, drain and skate pools. Now don't start packing your bags and booking flights here. The pools are all but gone, filled with sand or refurbished.  There are also more neighbors around and they like to call the cops. The city has been steadily coming back to life, in the years since the storm. But for the first few years after, we became the pioneers of pool skating in the Gulf south. I mentioned no names here, but if you were a part of this, then you know who you are." Epilogue-The 'Katrina Crew' have shown themselves to be 100% hardcore pool riders that do 'all it takes', in order to have those soulful sessions we all seek out. They are welcome to come skate in our neighborhoods anytime. Thanks to The 'Katrina Crew' for the awesome inspiration. Skate & do all that is necessary.-Ozzie

item.title: plaster blast
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4498" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Aaron Astorga -FS grind, mid cup- 'Lawyers'"][/caption] For putting up -politely- with my writing weirdness, I am giving you all an extra backyard blast today. This is Aaron Astorga,  a few weekends back. He's a coping destroyer...make no mistake on that one! Thank you to MRZ for the image. Thanks everyone for reading. Skate -Ozzie
